article: One morning, my son, Chilly, found a carpenterworm unexpectedly and put it in a jar. Each day he couldn't _ to visit the little guest. Few weeks later we discovered it _ in a cocoon . Chilly surely knew a moth or butterfly was about to be _ . He was _ to know what gift nature was about to give him. Gradually we found it half transparent and we could _ the wings of the unborn. Soon, a moth broke free, and then _ eggs, completing its life cycle. The next day, I _ Chilly it was time to set it free. He took it _ and opened the jar. It circled the yard twice, came back, and _ on Chilly's arm. He picked it up and threw it in the air. The moth repeated its _ pattern. He tried over and over, but each time it would _ to his arm so that Chilly had to give up. The next day he attempted to set it free again, and after a few repetitions the moth finally flew off into the grass. Like a _ , I believe the moth was afraid to _ what it was comfortable with. It wanted to stay with something _ , scared to move on and experience something unknown. I was once that little moth. My cocoon was my mother's _ , in which I was comfortable, and hated to fly too far away from it. I was _ when my first job required me to move to a new city. Humans are creatures of _ . We resist change. However, if I hadn't moved, I would not have experienced many _ and wonderful things or met many of my friends. So each move gave me the _ to learn and experience, but best of all, I met friends.
